_prev_prog_3.Description: Titan Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

    Titan Cold Storage uses anhydrous ammonia to maintain a cold environment per our client's needs.  As such, we recognize our responsibility to ensure the refrigeration system is run safely for the protection of our employees, our neighbors, and the environment.  To this end, we have conducted several in-depth studies (including Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits) to assure we are both in compliance with regulations and operating as safely and efficiently as possible.  

    All refrigeration system operators are fully trained in their duties prior to assignment to prevent accidental releases or incidents that could cause a release.  In addition, all facility employees have been trained per our emergency response program should an emergency situation arise.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Facility Overview



Titan Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruit, vegetables, and nuts in Bakersfield, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(6) Cold Storage Rooms

(8) Precool Rooms

(1) Glycol Chiller



Facility Location



Titan Cold Storage is located at 6001 Snow Rd, Bakersfield, CA 93308. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 35.424532, -119.066420. The facility is located approximately 750 feet west of state highway 99 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by businesses and residential areas.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard". Titan Cold Storage is located within the Oildale Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed the following faults within close proximity:

Kern Front Fault - <150 Years

Premier Fault - <150 Years

Unnamed Ground Breaks of 1952 Eart

hquake - <150 Years

New Hope Fault - <1,600,000 Years

Poso Creek Fault - <1,600,000 Years

Unnamed Faults East of Oildale - <1,600,000 Years



The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Titan Cold Storage has a 2-5% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



Description of Covered Process



The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



Most control valve groups are located in hallways to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the engine room. A partial list of system components includes:

(1) Reciprocating compressor

(4) Screw compressors

(3) Oil separators

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Main suction accumulator

(1) Auto-Purger

(1) Oil Separator

(1) Oil Pot

Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Accumulator

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Titan Cold Storage is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receiver

The purpose of the high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receiver receives high pressure liquid from the condensers and supplies high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receiver is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receiver contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulators

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Pots

The purpose of the glycol chiller oil pot is to provide a safe location to drain oil from the refrige

ration system. The glycol chiller oil pot receives liquid ammonia and oil from the glycol chiller and vents ammonia vapor back to the glycol chiller accumulator. The glycol chiller oil pot is equipped with a spring-return oil drain valve which is used to drain oil from the system as needed. Under normal conditions, the glycol chiller oil pot contains low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil. The purpose of the oil separator oil pot is to provide a means of returning oil to the compressors. The oil separator oil pot receives oil and high pressure vapor ammonia from Oil Separator 4 and vents ammonia vapor to the main suction accumulator. Once the oil separator oil pot is full, the oil is transferred back to the compressors. Under normal conditions, the oil separator oil pot contains high pressure vapor ammonia and refrigerant oil.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporators, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessels. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Glycol Chiller

The purpose of the glycol chiller (shell and tube heat exchanger) is to remove heat from the glycol solution being pumped through it. The glycol chiller receives liquid from a flooded accumulator where it is contained within the shell of the heat exchanger a

nd surrounds the tubes containing glycol solution. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the shell and tube heat exchanger and is returned to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the glycol chiller contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Glycol Chiller Accumulator

The purpose of the glycol chiller accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the glycol chiller and to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The glycol chiller accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The glycol chiller accumulator supplies, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the glycol chiller. Liquid and vapor returned from the glycol chiller is separated inside the glycol chiller accumulator to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. The glycol chiller accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the glycol chiller accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Main Suction Accumulator

The purpose of the main suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessels. The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessels

The purpose of the liquid transfer vessels is

to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessels receive liquid from the main suction accumulator. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessels reaches the float switches, the three way solenoid valves are energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessels to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessels can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator and glycol chiller accumulator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receiver. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver/thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Auto-Purger

The purpose of the auto-purger is to remove non-condensable gases from the system without requiring the system to be manually opened. The au

to-purger consists of the following components: water bubbler, foul gas line, liquid line, suction line, water line, drain line, and remote purge point solenoid valves. The auto-purger removes non-condensable gases by refrigerating the foul gas so that the ammonia vapor condenses to liquid and can be returned to the system. The non-condensable gases are removed from the system through the water bubbler. Under normal conditions, the auto-purger contains small quantities of ammonia and water. 

Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System

The engine room is equipped with two (2) ammonia detectors which will alert personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm through audible/visual alarms installed outside the engine room. If the concentration in the engine room reaches 150 ppm, the emergency ventilation system will be activated. Additional ammonia detectors are installed in each cold room, precool room, and in the chiller area. If the concentration in one of these rooms exceeds 10 ppm, the liquid feed solenoid valve(s) supplying the room/area is automatically closed. At 25 ppm, audible/visual alarms are activated. 



Emergency Control Box

The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the east wall of the engine room and contains three (3) valves. 

Valve #1: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Valve #3: High Side Discharge Valve

Opening the water valve near the mixing tank and valve #1 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening the water valve and Valve #3 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. The Emergency Control Box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equ

ipment from rupturing. All relief valves terminate to atmosphere, 7.25 or 15 ft above the roof. 



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:



High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.



Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.



High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.



Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices



Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:



High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.



Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch



The main suction accumulato

r is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

The interior entrance to the machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room.



Process Classification

The ammonia refrigeration system at Titan Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Titan Cold Storage is treated as a single process.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

    To ensure the ongoing safety of our facility, we have instituted a Process Safety Management program.  We have compiled written process safety information that includes the hazards of the process, the technology being utilized and detailed information on our equipment.  We conduct a Process Hazard Analysis every five years, ensuring to track all recommendations to closure.  All operators assist in the annual review of our operating procedures to ensure that both the SOPs are accurate, and to ensure each employee has been provided refresher training on them.  We also utilize safe work practices such as Lock-Out, Block-Out, Tag-Out, Confined Space Entry, Hot Works, Line Breaking, etcetera.

    To assure Mechanical Integrity, we perform detailed inspections on each piece of equipment in the system on an annual basis.  All inspections are performed per International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration Bulletin 109.  To assure the longevity of the process, we have also developed and implemented a Management of Change p

rogram.  Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are performed as needed.

    Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure our ongoing compliance with regulations.  We have also instituted procedures for Incident Investigations, Employee Participation, and Contractor Safety.

    Development, implementation, and documentation of the entire plan is the responsibility of the Plant Manager.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

    Titan Cold Storage has not had an accidental release nor any incident that could have resulted in the release of anhydrous ammonia in the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

    Titan Cold Storage has developed an emergency response program to ensure: Employee safety, Notification of agencies, and informing the general public.  This plan includes a chain of command, evacuation procedures, a notification list, and First Aid for exposure to either liquid or gaseous ammonia.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Titan Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Titan Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



Titan Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are assigned a responsible person and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented. 



For the future, Titan Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Titan Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Titan Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
